sentence.idiomatic: No matter where I go, I will always be part of this family.
We want to create our own brand.
Success belongs to those who can stick to the end.
He is a very stern coach. He has high expectations of the athletes.
In class, the teacher sternly criticized those students who were not diligent.
This time the government’s penalties for piracy are more severe.
Now everyone knows that he gave up willingly, no one advised him to do it.
Originally, I was not at all willing to leave. It was him that forced me to leave.
His friend begged him several times. In the end he had to lend him the money a little unwillingly.
It really puzzled everyone that she wouldn’t want to take such a good opportunity.
Sometimes I was puzzled by the decisions that I made. I don’t know whether if it's right or not.
I’m really puzzled. Why are there so many people indulge in computer games?
What she said before and now is contradictory. She is definitely lying.
Recently they contradicted each other at work, so they are ignoring each other.
After they've solved the dispute, they've made up again.
A locally born and bred farmer introduced the history of this village to him.
When he was traveling in Hainan, he got to know a tour guide who was native to Hainan.
People in this area for the most part believe in the native religion.
It’s almost graduation, but he is still at sea about work. He doesn’t know what he would like to do.
Recently a lot of problems have arisen in their marriage. It’s making her feeling very lost.
When faced with difficulties, I never feel at sea--I would bravely keep on going.
Love cannot be forced. You would be better to let things happen naturally.
I haven’t thought about what I want to do in the future. I just let nature to take it's course.
Now there is nothing to be done--just let nature take it's course.
Sometimes I really don’t know where I belong.
What do you mean?

Even though I grew up in the States, ours is a very traditional Chinese family. I’ve always lived with my mother and father. They’re a lot stricter than other American parents, so I’m not as free as my American friends. However, I’m really close to my parents.
Then was coming to China to learn Chinese your own decision, or did they tell you to do it?

They told me to do it. Actually, I wasn’t at all eager to leave California at first. I felt it was the best place in the world. Now, though, I really appreciate my freedom here. I can live independently, study, make friends.
So isn’t that good?

But I feel confused about my own identity. Here, everyone treats me like a Chinese person, and that gives me a lot of pressure. In reality, a lot of my ideas and habits are very American, so in that regard I’m really not Chinese at all.
Of course you’re Chinese. You just grew up in the USA.

(sigh) That’s where the contradiction lies. I often ask myself: where am I really from? I’m not completely American, but not totally Chinese either. And there’s another big question: my future. My boyfriend is a local Chinese guy. We are really happy together, but his family wants me to be a perfect Chinese wife. My personality is too independent, I just can’t accept their ideas. I don’t even want children. (sigh) My thoughts are such a mess. Who can possibly tell me what I’m supposed to do?
Actually, you don’t need to over analyze it. Just let the nature take it's course.
